summary: This document contains interviews and information regarding Alfredo Rodriguez, who worked as a house manager for Jeffrey Epstein. Rodriguez provided details about his employment, including witnessing inappropriate behavior involving underage girls and possessing documents related to Epstein's activities. The document also discusses Rodriguez's arrest for obstruction of justice and his interactions with law enforcement.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: Rodriguez worked for Jeffrey Epstein and provided information about his employment, including witnessing inappropriate behavior involving minors.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Epstein is the primary subject of the investigation, with numerous allegations of sexual misconduct involving minors.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Maxwell is mentioned as having instructed Rodriguez not to discuss events that occurred at Epstein's home.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: Rodriguez expressed a desire to sell documents to Edwards for $50,000.

persons.name: Julio Cesar Suarez
persons.context: Suarez was interviewed regarding his relationship with Rodriguez and his knowledge of Rodriguez's activities.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Goldberger contacted Rodriguez regarding legal representation after Rodriguez received a subpoena.

persons.name: Leslie LNU
persons.context: Rodriguez had a last contact with Epstein's organization through Leslie regarding a letter of reference.

persons.name: Sarah Kellan
persons.context: Kellan is mentioned in relation to instructions given to Rodriguez regarding payments.

persons.name: Jean Luc Brunel
persons.context: Brunel is mentioned as someone who would bring girls to Epstein's house.

persons.name: Jerome Pierre
persons.context: Pierre is mentioned as being aware of the sexual activities occurring at Epstein's house.

persons.name: Robert Couturier
persons.context: Couturier was interviewed regarding his interactions with Epstein and his discomfort with Epstein's behavior.

persons.name: Steven Hoffenberg
persons.context: Hoffenberg was contacted for information but refused to answer questions without an attorney present.

persons.name: James McCoskey
persons.context: McCoskey was interviewed regarding the homicide investigation of Arthur Shapiro, which had no connection to Epstein.

connections.description: Rodriguez worked for Epstein as a house manager.
Maxwell instructed Rodriguez not to discuss events at Epstein's home.
Rodriguez wanted to sell documents to Edwards.
Rodriguez and Suarez are friends who met through their wives.
Goldberger contacted Rodriguez for legal representation.
Brunel is mentioned as someone who brought girls to Epstein's house.
Pierre is mentioned as being aware of the sexual activities at Epstein's house.

events.title: Interview of Alfredo Rodriguez
events.description: Rodriguez was interviewed about his employment with Epstein and the information he possessed regarding underage girls.

events.title: Arrest of Alfredo Rodriguez
events.description: Rodriguez was arrested for obstruction of justice related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Investigation Initiation
events.description: The full investigation into Epstein's activities was initiated.

locations: 505 South Flagler Drive, Suite 500, Palm Beach, Florida
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez worked for Jeffrey Epstein as a house manager from 2004 to 2005.
Rodriguez witnessed underage girls at Epstein's residence and was aware of sexual activities involving minors.
Rodriguez possessed a black book with contact information for numerous individuals, many of whom were underage girls.
Rodriguez was arrested for obstruction of justice on December 8, 2009.
Rodriguez expressed fear of Epstein, which prevented him from reporting the misconduct to law enforcement.
